q: What are the main symptoms of infantile Tay-Sachs disease?
a: The main symptoms of infantile Tay-Sachs disease include being overly startled by noises and movement, being very slow to reach milestones, floppiness and weakness, difficulty swallowing, loss of vision or hearing, muscle stiffness, and seizures.

q: How is Tay-Sachs disease inherited?
a: Tay-Sachs disease is inherited when both parents have the faulty gene. If both parents are carriers, there's a chance the child may inherit the faulty gene and develop Tay-Sachs disease.

q: When should I seek medical advice if I suspect Tay-Sachs disease?
a: You should speak to your GP if you're planning a pregnancy and have a family history of Tay-Sachs disease, if you're pregnant and concerned your baby could have the disease, or if your child is showing symptoms.

q: Is there a cure for Tay-Sachs disease?
a: Currently, there is no cure for Tay-Sachs disease. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and improving quality of life.

q: What treatments are available for Tay-Sachs disease?
a: Treatments for Tay-Sachs disease may include medication for seizures and stiffness, speech and language therapy, physiotherapy, and antibiotics to treat infections.
